Ryman Auditorium (Nashville, Tenn.); Grand ole opry (Radio program); Country music -- Tennessee -- Nashville; Country musicians; Theaters -- Tennessee -- Nashville -- History; Nashville (Tenn.) -- History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Photograph shows twelve individuals, five of whom appear to be performing. (None are identified in the photograph.) A barn faade is in the background with a sign over the doors reading, "WSM Grand Ole Opry." The back of a audience member's head appears in the lower right corner.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection, 1937-1976
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Grand Ole Opry is a radio variety show featuring country music entertainers performing before a live audience. The program began in October 1925, sponsored by the Nashville-based National Life and Accident Insurance Company. The insurance company's motto was "We Shield Millions." The initials provided the call letters for WSM, the radio station that broadcasts the Opry.
